com.albroco.barebonesdigest

Class DigestChallenge

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.albroco.barebonesdigest.DigestChallenge

  • public class DigestChallenge
extends java.lang.Object
    Represents a HTTP digest challenge, as sent from the server to the client in a WWW-Authenticate HTTP header.

    Parsing the WWW-Authenticate header

    When the server receives a request that requires authorization it can respond with response code 401 and include a WWW-Authenticate response header. The header includes one or more challenges, some of which may be HTTP Digest challenges.

    To parse a HTTP Digest challenge pass it to the parse(String) method. Note that the HTTP Digest challenge must first be extracted from the header value if the header contains multiple challenges, see WwwAuthenticateHeader.

    Quoted and unquoted values

    Where applicable there are two getters for each directive, one for the quoted value (exactly as it appears in the challenge), and one for the unquoted value (with escape sequences parsed and surrounding quotes removed). Quoting is defined in RFC 2616, Section 2.2.

    Concurrency

    This class is thread safe.

    Limitations

    All values are parsed but not all values are stored. In particular, the following is not stored:
    • Unrecognized directives.
    • Supported "quality of protection" values except for the standard ones, "auth" and "auth-int".
    See Also:
    WwwAuthenticateHeader, RFC 2617, Section 3.2.1, The WWW-Authenticate Response Header, RFC 7235, Section 14.47, WWW-Authenticate

    • Method Detail

      • isDigestChallenge

        public static boolean isDigestChallenge(java.lang.String challenge)
        Returns true if a string represents a HTTP Digest challenge (which may or may not be valid).

        This method just checks that the string starts with the HTTP challenge prefix, it does not verify that the challenge is correct. The prefix identifies the challenge type (basic, digest, etc.), so if this method returns true the string is either a valid HTTP digest challenge or not a valid challenge of any type.

        Parameters:
        challenge - the string to check
        Returns:
        true if the string is a HTTP digest challenge

      • parse

        public static DigestChallenge parse(java.lang.String challengeString)
                             throws ChallengeParseException
        Parses a HTTP Digest challenge.
        Parameters:
        challengeString - the challenge as a string
        Returns:
        the parsed challenge
        Throws:
        ChallengeParseException - if the challenge is malformed
        See Also:
        RFC 2617, Section 3.2.1, The WWW-Authenticate Response Header

      • getQuotedRealm

        public java.lang.String getQuotedRealm()
        Returns the quoted version of the mandatory realm directive, exactly as it appears in the challenge. The realm directive is described in Section 3.2.1 of RFC 2617:
        realm
        A string to be displayed to users so they know which username and password to use. This string should contain at least the name of the host performing the authentication and might additionally indicate the collection of users who might have access. An example might be "registered_users@gotham.news.com".
        Returns:
        The quoted value of the realm directive, exactly as it appears in the challenge

      • getRealm

        public java.lang.String getRealm()
        Returns the unquoted version of the mandatory realm directive. The realm directive is described in Section 3.2.1 of RFC 2617:
        realm
        A string to be displayed to users so they know which username and password to use. This string should contain at least the name of the host performing the authentication and might additionally indicate the collection of users who might have access. An example might be "registered_users@gotham.news.com".
        Returns:
        The unquoted value of the realm directive

      • getQuotedDomain

        public java.lang.String getQuotedDomain()
        Returns the quoted version of the optional domain directive, exactly as it appears in the challenge, or null if the domain is not set. The domain directive is described in Section 3.2.1 of RFC 2617:
        domain
        A quoted, space-separated list of URIs, as specified in RFC XURI, that define the protection space. […]
        Returns:
        The quoted value of the domain directive, exactly as it appears in the challenge, or null if the challenge does not contain the domain directive.

      • getDomain

        public java.lang.String getDomain()
        Returns the unquoted version of the optional domain directive, or null if the domain is not set. The domain directive is described in Section 3.2.1 of RFC 2617:
        domain
        A quoted, space-separated list of URIs, as specified in RFC XURI, that define the protection space. […]
        Returns:
        The unquoted value of the domain directive

      • getAlgorithm

        public java.lang.String getAlgorithm()
        Returns the value of the algorithm directive if present. The algorithm directive is described in Section 3.2.1 of RFC 2617:
        algorithm
        A string indicating a pair of algorithms used to produce the digest and a checksum. If this is not present it is assumed to be "MD5". If the algorithm is not understood, the challenge should be ignored (and a different one used, if there is more than one). […]
        Returns:
        The value of the algorithm directive or null if the algorithm directive is not present in the header

      • getQuotedNonce

        public java.lang.String getQuotedNonce()
        Returns the quoted version of the mandatory nonce directive, exactly as it appears in the challenge. The nonce directive is described in Section 3.2.1 of RFC 2617:
        nonce
        A server-specified data string which should be uniquely generated each time a 401 response is made. It is recommended that this string be base64 or hexadecimal data. Specifically, since the string is passed in the header lines as a quoted string, the double-quote character is not allowed.

        The contents of the nonce are implementation dependent. The quality of the implementation depends on a good choice. […]

        The nonce is opaque to the client.

        Returns:
        The quoted value of the nonce directive, exactly as it appears in the challenge

      • getNonce

        public java.lang.String getNonce()
        Returns the unquoted version of the mandatory nonce directive. The nonce directive is described in Section 3.2.1 of RFC 2617:
        nonce
        A server-specified data string which should be uniquely generated each time a 401 response is made. It is recommended that this string be base64 or hexadecimal data. Specifically, since the string is passed in the header lines as a quoted string, the double-quote character is not allowed.

        The contents of the nonce are implementation dependent. The quality of the implementation depends on a good choice. […]

        The nonce is opaque to the client.

        Returns:
        the unquoted value of the nonce directive

      • getQuotedOpaque

        public java.lang.String getQuotedOpaque()
        Returns the quoted version of the opaque directive exactly as it appears in the challenge, or null if the directive is not present. The opaque directive is described in Section 3.2.1 of RFC 2617:
        opaque
        A string of data, specified by the server, which should be returned by the client unchanged in the Authorization header of subsequent requests with URIs in the same protection space. It is recommended that this string be base64 or hexadecimal data.
        Returns:
        the quoted value of the opaque directive or null if the opaque directive is not present in the header

      • getOpaque

        public java.lang.String getOpaque()
        Returns the unquoted version of the opaque directive, or null if the directive is not present. The opaque directive is described in Section 3.2.1 of RFC 2617:
        opaque
        A string of data, specified by the server, which should be returned by the client unchanged in the Authorization header of subsequent requests with URIs in the same protection space. It is recommended that this string be base64 or hexadecimal data.
        Returns:
        the quoted value of the opaque directive or null if the opaque directive is not present in the header

      • getSupportedQopTypes

        public java.util.Set<DigestChallenge.QualityOfProtection> getSupportedQopTypes()
        Returns the types of "quality of protection" listed in the challenge as supported by the server.

        Only the two standard quality of protection types ("auth" and "auth-int") are included in the result, other non-standard qop types are ignored.

        Returns:
        the supported quality of protection types

      • isStale

        public boolean isStale()
        Returns a boolean representation of the stale directive. This method returns true if the header has a stale directive that is equal to "true" (case-insensitive). If there is no stale directive or it has any other value, false is returned. The stale directive is described in Section 3.2.1 of RFC 2617:
        stale
        A flag, indicating that the previous request from the client was rejected because the nonce value was stale. If stale is TRUE (case-insensitive), the client may wish to simply retry the request with a new encrypted response, without reprompting the user for a new username and password. The server should only set stale to TRUE if it receives a request for which the nonce is invalid but with a valid digest for that nonce (indicating that the client knows the correct username/password). If stale is FALSE, or anything other than TRUE, or the stale directive is not present, the username and/or password are invalid, and new values must be obtained.
        Returns:
        true if a stale directive is present in the header and equal to "true" (case-insensitive), false otherwise.
